title-group.article-title: Delayed dural graft breakdown and intracranial hypotension following posterior fossa decompression and duraplasty for Chiari malformation type I: illustrative case

contrib-group.aff: 1Department of Neurological Surgery, Renaissance School of Medicine at Stony Brook University, Stony Brook, New York
2Department of Pediatrics, Renaissance School of Medicine at Stony Brook University, Stony Brook, New York

author-notes.corresp: Correspondence David A. Chesler: Renaissance School of Medicine at Stony Brook University, Stony Brook, NY. david.chesler@stonybrookmedicine.edu.

fn.p: INCLUDE WHEN CITING Published February 10, 2025; DOI: 10.3171/CASE24715.
Disclosures The authors report no conflict of interest concerning the materials or methods used in this study or the findings specified in this paper.

sec.title: BACKGROUND
sec.p: Chiari malformations type I are commonly encountered in pediatric patients. Posterior fossa decompression with or without duraplasty is recommended for patients with intractable symptoms, as well as those showing evidence of brainstem dysfunction.

sec.title: OBSERVATIONS
sec.p: In this report, the authors describe the case of a 19-year-old female who presented to the neurosurgery clinic with delayed synthetic dural graft breakdown as well as associated pseudomeningocele and intracranial hypotension. She underwent exploration and revision of her duraplasty, where a dural defect measuring 1.5 cm in diameter was observed. The defect was not contiguous with peripheral sutures. The defect was repaired with a pericranium autograft and reinforced with dural sealants. Her postoperative course was complicated by scalp dysesthesia.

sec.title: LESSONS
sec.p: To the authors’ knowledge, this is the first reported case of a synthetic dural graft breakdown following posterior fossa decompression with duraplasty.

kwd-group.title: ABBREVIATIONS
kwd-group.kwd: CISS = constructive interference in steady state

body.p: Chiari malformations type I (CM-Is) are commonly encountered in pediatric patients, with an estimated radiographic prevalence of 1.0%–3.5%.1,2 Although there is substantial variability in clinical presentation, the most common symptoms include occipital or upper cervical pain exacerbated by Valsalva maneuvers as well as headaches, which can be accompanied by neck, shoulder, or back pain. Motor and sensory changes, as well as cranial nerve, brainstem (e.g., respiratory or feeding abnormalities), and cerebellar dysfunction, have also been noted.1,3 However, up to 68% of radiographically diagnosed CM-Is are asymptomatic.2

Asymptomatic or minimally symptomatic patients without a sizable syrinx tend to be managed conservatively; clinical and radiographic progression tends to be rare, and up to 42% of symptomatic patients report a reduction in symptom severity over time.4–7 Decompression tends to be recommended for patients with intractable symptoms and those with signs of brainstem dysfunction, such as dysphagia or sleep apnea.5,8

Surgery aims to restore cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) circulation around the foramen magnum by decompressing the posterior fossa. This is often accomplished with occipital craniectomy and C1 laminectomy.8,9 The addition of duraplasty and tonsillar resection remains controversial and highly patient specific. Although associated with an increased risk of short-term postoperative complications, there is conflicting evidence regarding the degree of symptomatic improvement and need for reoperation when duraplasty is compared to extradural compression alone.10–12

In this report, we present the case of a 19-year-old female who initially underwent a suboccipital decompression at age 12 years with delayed development of a dural graft breakdown with symptomatic pseudomeningocele. A central defect not in communication with the peripheral suture lines was observed intraoperatively. To our knowledge, we report the first case of dural graft breakdown following posterior fossa decompression with duraplasty.

sec.title: History and Presentations
sec.p: A patient presented to the neurosurgery clinic at 12 years of age for the evaluation of a CM-I initially noted on magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) performed as part of a workup for intermittent but progressive difficulties with coordination in the context of sensorineural hearing loss since age 4 years, despite a normal newborn hearing screen. At this time, the patient described episodic occipital headaches during periods of vigorous exercise but denied exacerbation with tussive maneuvers. A neurologist also evaluated the patient for bilateral numbness and paresthesia of her lower extremities, which extended from her ankles to the hallux and sole of the medial foot. She denied any other motor or sensory symptoms, with no abnormal findings on physical examination.

MRI of the brain and cervical, thoracic, and lumbar spine performed without intravenous contrast showed a descent of the cerebellar tonsils approximately 6–7 mm below the foramen magnum with associated crowding. Electromyography and nerve conduction studies of her bilateral lower extremities revealed no abnormalities.

Elective operative intervention was recommended, and the patient underwent a suboccipital craniectomy with a C1 laminectomy and expansive duraplasty. The craniectomy was 3 cm × 3 cm in length with a Y-shaped dural opening. Outflow to the fourth ventricle was visualized with separation of the cerebellar tonsils. Duraplasty was performed by circumferentially suturing DuraMatrix Suturable (Collagen Matrix, Inc.) to the dura. A CSF leak was not noted on Valsalva maneuvers, and the dural repair was covered with Adherus dural sealant (HyperBranch Medical Technology, Inc.).

The patient’s postoperative course was uncomplicated. Non–contrast-enhanced MRI of the brain with the cine flow protocol on postoperative day 2 showed expected postoperative changes, with adequate decompression of the foramen magnum and improved flow dorsal to the cerebellum (Fig. 1A). Follow-up MRI at 2 months demonstrated stable findings with an unchanged 3 × 3 × 5–cm asymptomatic fluid collection within the dorsal subcutaneous tissues (Fig. 1B). FIG. 1.
A: Postoperative sagittal T2-weighted CISS MRI 2 days after suboccipital craniectomy with duraplasty. A 3 × 3 × 5–cm posterior fluid collection was noted in the suboccipital soft tissues. B: Sagittal T2-weighted MRI of the cervical spine 2 months postoperatively demonstrated a stable posterior suboccipital fluid collection.

At the 1-, 2-, and 3-month follow-up visits, the patient noticed an improvement in her headaches and balance and complete resolution of her preoperative paresthesias. However, 6 months postoperatively, she described a recurrence of her exercise-induced headaches with decreased severity but stable frequency as compared to her preoperative symptoms. Given concerns for her recurrent symptoms, brain MRI with and without contrast was performed, showing a decrease in the size of the posterior fluid collection, which now measured 1.3 × 2.6 × 4.5 cm (Fig. 2). No syrinx was noted in the cervical spine. The patient was advised to follow up with the neurology service for additional evaluation but was subsequently lost to follow-up. FIG. 2.
A: Postoperative sagittal T2-weighted fluid-attenuated inversion recovery MRI of the brain 6 months after suboccipital craniectomy with duraplasty. There was a fluid signal intensity collection in the suboccipital soft tissues at the craniectomy site measuring 1.3 × 2.6 × 4.5 cm and likely representing postsurgical change. The cerebellar tonsils were unchanged in position. B: Sagittal T1-weighted MRI of the cervical spine 6 months postoperatively. A stable posterior suboccipital fluid collection was again visualized.

The patient re-presented to the neurosurgery clinic at age 18 years with medically refractory positional headaches. She described these as diffusely frontal with pressure behind the eyes, which worsened when she lay flat. She reported that these were different from her prior occipital headaches. Neurological examination findings were unremarkable. MRI of the brain and cervical spine before this visit was significant for a pseudomeningocele measuring 3.7 × 0.8 × 0.8 cm with an associated dural defect not present on previous studies (Fig. 3A). Given concerns for a possible infectious etiology versus intracranial hypotension (the latter given her positional symptoms), contrast-enhanced MRI and magnetic resonance venography studies of the brain were performed. The magnetic resonance venogram showed slight prominence of the venous sinuses (Fig. 3B), with no additional findings noted on MRI of the brain. It was hypothesized that the patient was experiencing low-pressure headaches given the dural defect, and the decision was made to proceed with an exploration and revision of her duraplasty. FIG. 3.
A: A sagittal fast imaging employing steady-state acquisition (FIESTA) MRI sequence was obtained at age 18 years, 6 years after surgery. There was a posterior dural defect (white arrow) with an associated posterior fluid collection likely representing a pseudomeningocele measuring 3.7 × 0.8 × 0.8 cm. B: Sagittal T1-weighted MRI with contrast demonstrating distension of the venous sinuses and sagging of the brainstem consistent with intracranial hypotension.

sec.title: Operation
sec.p: A 10-blade scalpel was used to open the skin along the prior incision, dissecting down through the subcutaneous tissues and into the midline avascular plane to the area of the previous decompression. A collection under pressure was encountered, which was opened, revealing CSF. The free edges of the previous dural patch were carefully dissected, revealing a well-demarcated dural defect, approximately 1.5 cm in diameter, in the center of the prior duraplasty. CSF egress was noted, but the defect was not in contact with peripheral suture lines.

Pericranium autografting was performed to repair the defect with a 2 × 2–cm piece of pericranium harvested along the left lateral occipital convexity. The dural defect was repaired with this autograft using circumferential running CV-6 GORE-TEX sutures (W. L. Gore & Associates, Inc.). Mild CSF leakage was observed at the suture line, so an EVARREST fibrin sealant patch (Ethicon Inc.) was applied to reinforce the repair, followed by a layer of Adherus dural sealant spray. Closure was performed in layers: the suboccipital and paraspinal muscles, as well as the dorsal cervical fascia, were closed with 0 Vicryl sutures (Ethicon Inc.). The deep dermal layer was approximated with 3-0 Vicryl sutures, and a running 3-0 Monocryl suture was used for the skin.

sec.title: Postoperative Course
sec.p:
The patient was admitted to the neurocritical care unit postoperatively, downgraded to intermediate care on postoperative day 1, and discharged on postoperative day 3. An MRI cine flow study obtained on postoperative day 0 showed persistence of the CSF fluid collection and adequate ventral and dorsal flow through the foramen magnum. The patient was evaluated in the clinic in 1 month and described improvement in her preoperative headaches but noted dysesthetic pain in the right parietal scalp, which extended down through her incision. She was prescribed gabapentin 100 mg to be taken three times daily and was advised to follow up in 3 months with brain and cervical spine constructive interference in steady state (CISS) MRI and cine flow protocol (Fig. 4). FIG. 4.
A: Sagittal FIESTA MRI sequence of the brain at age 19 years, 3 months postrevision surgery. There was an interval increased adjacent posterior extracranial CSF isointense collection with peripheral enhancement, possibly communicating with the meninges, with internal flow going in and out at the mid-region, extending down to the C3 level, representing an increased pseudomeningocele measuring up to approximately 3.2 × 3.6 × 6.3 cm. On CSF flow imaging, there was flow through the foramen magnum. B: Sagittal T2-weighted MRI of the cervical spine with contrast 3 months after revision surgery with no evidence of a focal marrow–replacing lesion or abnormal spinal cord signal intensity or enhancement.

Nine months postoperatively, the patient reported resolution of her nerve pain and had discontinued the Neurontin. She has returned to activities for the most part. She reported headaches 1–2 times per week, waking her from sleep and associated with photophobia, hyperacusis, and occasional nausea and vomiting. She denied any blurry vision and could not identify factors inciting, exacerbating, or relieving headaches. She stated, though, that these headaches werre distinctly different from the positional headache she had experienced before her repeat CM-I surgery. These headaches did not appear to represent low-pressure headaches, as there was no evidence of positionality to them, nor did they seem to be related to intracranial hypertension, as there was a progressive decrease in the size of her residual pseudomeningocele (Fig. 5). FIG. 5.
A: Sagittal T2-weighted MRI of the brain at age 19 years, 9 months after revision surgery. There was an interval decrease in the pseudomeningocele, measuring up to approximately 2.0 × 1.3 × 4.8 cm. Ventricles were of normal size, and there was no compression at the foramen magnum. B: Sagittal T2-weighted MRI of the cervical spine with contrast 9 months after revision surgery with no evidence of a focal marrow–replacing lesion or abnormal spinal cord signal intensity or enhancement.

sec.title: Informed Consent
sec.p: The necessary informed consent was obtained in this study.

sec.title: Observations
sec.p: Pseudomeningoceles are common following posterior fossa decompression, with a median complication rate of 15% in pediatric patients.13 Although a radiographic or clinical pseudomeningocele is often recognized within several weeks of surgery, a delayed presentation has been reported.14–17 Here, we report the case of a 19-year-old female who presented with a delayed symptomatic pseudomeningocele with evidence of intracranial hypotension following a suboccipital craniectomy with duraplasty for CM-I. A defect in the synthetic dural graft was recognized on MRI at age 18 years and visually confirmed intraoperatively. To our knowledge, this is the first reported case of synthetic dural graft breakdown following posterior fossa decompression.

While the etiology of a postoperative pseudomeningocele is uncertain, it is often attributed to small tears within the dura or dural graft and CSF leakage through sutures.14 Dural graft selection can also influence CSF-related complication rates. The incidence of pseudomeningocele appears to be higher among patients who received a nonautologous graft than those receiving an autologous (e.g., galea-pericranium) graft. There were no apparent differences in functional outcomes (i.e., symptom relief, quality of life) between the grafts.11,14,18 Pericranium grafts are also nonimmunogenic and are associated with decreased rates of aseptic meningitis.19 However, the additional dissection necessary to harvest pericranium can result in an increased operative time and can increase the risk of irritation or injury to occipital nerves (as seen in this patient).20

Alterations in intracranial dynamics can also offer insight into pseudomeningocele formation. Phase-based amplified MRI demonstrated increased brainstem and cerebellar displacement in a pediatric patient with a CM-I compared to a healthy child.21 A preprint manuscript comparing fourteen subjects with a CM-I reported similar results, with significantly increased anterior-posterior and superior-inferior displacement of tonsils in the patients with CM-I compared to healthy controls.22 Comparing the rates of CSF-related posterior fossa surgery complications in patients with and without CMs is a possible topic for further research.

The prevention of a pseudomeningocele in posterior fossa decompression focuses on attaining a watertight closure between the dura and graft. Dural sealants are often used to augment primary closure to reduce the risk of CSF leaks from suture holes. However, despite using fibrin- and hydrogel-based dural sealants intraoperatively, there is conflicting evidence regarding their effectiveness in preventing CSF leakage.23–27

Our case report has several limitations. Despite recommending regular neurosurgical clinic visits, the patient was lost to follow-up for 5 years until presenting again with intractable symptoms. As a result, we are unable to evaluate the evolution of the patient’s symptoms in relation to the postsurgical fluid collection and the timing of dural graft breakdown. We could also not assess the long-term success of dural sealant–reinforced pericranium autograft, given that our follow-up is limited to only 9 months after revision surgery.

sec.title: Lessons
sec.p: A delayed pseudomeningocele with dural graft breakdown is a rare complication of posterior fossa decompression with duraplasty. During revision surgery, we used a pericranium autograft and several dural sealants to ensure watertight closure. Despite careful harvesting of the pericranium, our patient developed postoperative occipital dysesthesias requiring pharmacological intervention.

sec.title: Acknowledgments
sec.p: We thank the Department of Neurosurgery at the Renaissance School of Medicine at Stony Brook University for their continued support and care of our patients.

sec.title: Disclosures
sec.p: The authors report no conflict of interest concerning the materials or methods used in this study or the findings specified in this paper.

sec.title: Author Contributions
sec.p: Conception and design: all authors. Acquisition of data: all authors. Analysis and interpretation of data: all authors. Drafting the article: all authors. Critically revising the article: all authors. Reviewed submitted version of manuscript: all authors. Approved the final version of the manuscript on behalf of all authors: Chesler. Study supervision: Chesler.
